transcript.content: Kevin King Transcription REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Kevin King 19 years old when I caught this charge I've been here for 28 years serving a life sentence.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So tell me a little bit about the folks who raised you?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: My mom and my dad they really was 2 good parents it never was them it always was me leaving the house it was the environment that I was surrounded by that always got me caught up or got me in trouble.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Where were you where do you grow up?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: New Orleans.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Where about.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Desire housing projects ninth ward.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh yeah sure are your parents still alive?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: My dad is, my mom she died like 3 or 4 years ago.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay can you tell me the last memory you have of her?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: A phone call that I had called and we were discussing something she told me something that she had a dream that I'd be like in my 40s or something like that before I come home when I come home and stuff like that but that was the last time I really conversated with her after that when I called again they was telling me she was dead.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah one of the things I've seen with guys here is the difficulty with dealing with people passing away. Who comes and visits you here still?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: My sisters they come once a year they in Alaska.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah they come once a year.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: They come for the rodeo?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: No they just come visit me and my girl I'm with right now the girl I was with when I got arrested on this charge she's still with me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: 28 years she come see me. So.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How often do you get visits from her?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: She coming on the 23 and the 22 of this month right here that's about next week from now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and she's pretty regular?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah she stays in Houston,

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok so you say your mom and dad they weren't the problem is what you said so would it be safe to say that your childhood as you were coming up you felt loved and cared for?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah very much,

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You didn't feel neglected or abused in any way.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: No not at all like I said my mom and my dad they did their best. They did everything it was to be done to make sure me and my sisters and brothers had so it never was in the house it always was me leaving the house and who I was hanging with and my dad always never did like the people I used to hang with but I still choose to hang with that group and outside of that they showed me beacoup love

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Where were you in the birth order of your other siblings?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I'm the third to the oldest.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and what did your parents do for a living?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: My dad always did ran a bar room.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: He always did have his own business and always did bar room my mom she worked at the old folks home she would basically there till she passed away, retired and everything.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok were there any other adults that took an interest in you that you saw as kind of a parent figure?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah my mom's sister.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok tell me about her?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: She always understand well she always loved to talk to me she always loved to just come and get me always just one of the ones that you could always just call and ask where I was at and so like I said my mom and them they always work and my auntie did, she worked but she never did work as much as my mom and my dad so she always was the one that always kind of like kept a tab on us while they was gone.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Like what we had where we going stuff like that so she was the one that really was a second mom to me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay yeah. What's your last memory of her?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: She's still living I just talked to her about 3 4 days ago.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh good.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: So we always talking. Every chance I get we talk on the phone and stuff like that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay so the desire projects are gone.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you're going to have to paint a picture for me so if I'm sitting in front of your house. Ok back when we were probably we're probably the same age probably we were both like 18, 19.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can you paint it what would I be seeing and hearing and smelling.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: You would be seeing a lot of chaotics you'd be hearing a lot of dog barking and cussing police sirens. People running probably a few gun shots it was very it was chaotic. It wasn't nothing sweet bout the project the project was whatever you made it out of that's what you was going to get out the project whether you was in it or not.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: If you was in it you always had the option not to hang with the people that was in there. So it was basically chaotic it was there were times you came outside you saw something negative you very rarely saw something positive

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Was there a lot of fights?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yes that was one of the one of the major issues fighting we had to really do that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Kind of to survive.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah to really kind of like fit in it was like if you didn't do that or you didn't or you walked away from it you was going to be picked on you was going to be teased you was going to be called names you was really just going to be a target and so it's basically before it was like yeah he going to do this he going to do that but if you didn't you going to be the one that they always target kind of like put you down this this random just mess with you.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. What you just described sounds like what a lot of guys described about the first few years in prison.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: It's the same up in here it's what you make it out of up in here it's the thing that's going up here it's one or two things going to happen you usually going to get broke or you're either going to make it it's how strong you stay strong.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah tell me about that so what happens to the people who cannot handle it.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: They either get pumped up turn out or either just running from they problems turn out to be rats for security stuff like that it's it ain't nothing good man. It's basically nothing that good and but when I came here you had to just man up.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: If you didn't man up you was going to get messed over and me at 19 young good looking. Everybody looking at you you're a target if you get that target off your back then you not going to be no target no more you going to be well respected. Don't mess with him.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember what you had to do you remember a specific thing that you had to do to communicate that you're not a target.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I just man up because everything that was going on I challenged it I didn't back down I didn't explain myself I just attacked it and that was one of the biggest things that really got a lot of talk as far as people looking at me negative like he's going to really do this or he going to really do that so don't mess with him and so that was one of the main reasons right there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you find yourself getting into a lot of trouble here when you first came in?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yes very much.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok I'm going to get to that in a little bit I still want to talk a little bit about life before here. You said that you were hanging out with folks that your dad didn't really approve of. These are friends of yours.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Neighborhood friends.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: They were friends.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: And then I really assumed that they were my friends because they never was into what I was into.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What were you into?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I was into sports basketball football running track stuff like that that's something I did all my life. And for me to get out the problem that I was in far as the neighborhood stuff that's what I was gone do go to the park play basketball and play football and things like that but outside of that when I don't do that that's when I'm with the neighborhood friends.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok well tell me about them what are they up to?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Well half of them up here, up here with me wasn't like I said there really wasn't nothing good out of that they didn't have no father figures they didn't have no guides they didn't have nobody to really look over or look at or say that I don't want to do this I'm going to go do that.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I had that my dad always did a lot of positive things with me far as taking me fishing bring me to the bar room try to show me how to do this and do that he never wanted me to stay in the hood which was what was the hood was about so that was one of my biggest concerns with him.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Far as the people that were in my neighborhood then you can see the good things that my dad used to do he used to always want to try to come with me well we used to go fishing but we never did want them to come because they never did nothing outside of that. To show him that they was about positive stuff

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: So he felt like if he took him with me we gone be chaos on this fishing trip something like that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. I get that.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah so yeah like I said the hood never was good.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah so what about school how was school for you.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: School was good I used to do my thing at school like I said sports.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah where were you in school.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Nichols, Calvert. I bounced around.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay did you ever get kicked out of school?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Never.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay what was your last year of school?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: My ninth grade before I caught this charge.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah. This charge right here. I dropped out in ninth then I caught this charge I'm on right now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So let me so you were 19 when you caught this were you arrested before that?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me a little bit about that?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I was a juvenile. I was like 15 14 years old. I went to Scotland. I was on probation for auto theft violating my probation for auto theft another theft charge and they sentenced me to Scotland like 3 years and 15… yeah 3 years came home stayed home like a year or something then caught this charge am on right now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So it's kind of your school was kind of interrupted by that.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you have a particular memory of school a good memory or a bad memory of school something that sticks out with you still?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Not really because I never, I had I didn't stay growing up to have a good memory before sports football basketball that's the only good thing I remember about being in school.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: That's basically it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok if it wasn't this charge it sounds to me from what you're telling me that your life had already started going down the wrong path.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you think what do you think would have happened to you had you not gotten this charge.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I probably would have been improved I'd try to go back to school they did let me went back to school when I came home in 88 but I detoured. I detoured because the drugs the selling drugs was a downfall for me because I sold drugs. I was selling drugs and outside of that I probably would have been in a pro because I was a good athlete.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. A lot of guys when I ask them that question they say they might have been dead do you think that would be fair for you or not.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: No because at the time I came home in 88 a lot of people that loved me that cared for me didn't want me to do some of the things I was doing. I just choose to sell drugs and outside of me selling drugs caused me to come to jail that I'm on charge I'm on right now. So I don't think I'd have been dead.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay so a lot of I also understand that if you're selling drugs you almost everyone say you're selling drugs you need to have a firearm so did you have easy access to a firearm.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yes I did.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah it was man told me I had to have one to do that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me a little bit about you said that there's still a woman that comes to visit you to this day let's tell me a little bit about her who is this.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: That's Kim that's my baby she I love her very much I wish I'd have told her then how much I loved her before I caught this charge like I'm telling her right now. That I'm saying that's my baby that's the love of my life right there. I never loved a woman cared about a woman until me and her really got serious far as me being in jail. What I'm saying she had been in and out of my life since I been down but she 100% with me though.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah it's unusual.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: It is.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Someone to stick with the person that loves you. Do you have any children?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: No she was the one that was pregnant for me and she had a miscarriage due to the fact that I end up getting the time I got it kind of like stressed her out and it caused her to lose the child

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh no. So if there was one cause if I assume it's complicated lots of different things if there's one reason that you think that kind of got you into the situation got you down the road that you were on some people say yeah it was drugs or it was this or I was hanging with the wrong people what would it be for you.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I say the wrong people.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I say it's the wrong people that got me right here in the penitentiary but it's so really hard to say what got me in here or what the cause me come back to jail or whatever it was because the hood man the hood

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah I know what I understand I really do you were in a chaotic environment right I get that. Were drugs and alcohol part of your life I mean consuming them?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I never did drugs in my life. My dad mom nobody that I know of did drugs did drugs in my family.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay alright. So I'm going to switch gears a little bit and talk about coming here but I think is there something else about you before you came here that's important that you think we should know something that you didn't ask you about at this point from life before Angola.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: No.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, can you take a minute there to describe the Kevin King who was on the bus coming through the gates of Angola what was that, what was that kid like?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I knew what I was coming into I knew the environment I was coming into it was Angola I knew what I had to do to survive in Angola and that was my mindset not to be punked up not to be messed around not to be pushed around that that was basically my mindset and when I knew that Angola was crazy chaotic and yeah so I knew what I had to do to survive when I first got here but now it's is I'm humble man

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I'm so humble to the point to where is don't nothing bother me now I done did so much stuff in here to get a reputation and now that I got that its don't nothing bother me I can talk to other people now about this type of stuff what I'm saying but to be in a penitentiary right now it's like they got it made. They don't have to be challenged they don't have to be pushed around they just come in the jail

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Well I what do you think changed everybody talks about Angola from when you came here it's like a different universe.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: It is if you, I can't put my finger on it I really can't say what I know it's not the penitentiary it was when I got here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah why do you think it changed?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I think because a lot of old people that was here went home. A lot of people that's chaotic that thought they couldn't go home went home and they got a lot of youngsters here now that really don't know nothing about the penitentiary they don't even know if they doing time.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I used to tell myself and a few partners of mine man I'm not being here 10 years but I've been here 28 years and it don't even feel like 28 years so it's the same set just different environment this how they doing they time they not doing they time with chaotic and nothing like that they just doing they time just to be just here waiting on an open hand. And they'll never get it

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah I think I don't know maybe you can tell me this but it seems to me that if you got a whole bunch of people that are doing life without the possibility of parole. I mean they really start to think this is my world now this is my society this is my community and I don't want it to be this violent chaotic place because some of the guys who tell me it was the older guys who decided we don't want to live like this and that's when some of the changes happened in terms of how violent it was and how much people were challenged and so forth do you think that's true?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Somewhat it is. It's like that but like I said a lot of old heads that they been here gone home a lot of people that thought that they wasn't going to go home gone home. The youngsters that's coming her now they can't see what's in front of them they can't see that people really do mean life.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: That you really going to be here until something good happen and I'm one of the ones that's still here waiting on something good to happen but you could talk to the with the group of people that's coming in here right now you couldn't talk to the ones when I came in cause it was if you was talking to me I think you was trying to do something.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: But now you can talk to a group of people right now and get your point across and hope they hear you or hear you cry or hear what you talking about and wake them up and let them know that you really is in the penitentiary for a long time people mean life they mean life they got point look out 3 now they only had point look out 1 when I first came here. So you either going to die here or you going to get to go home one of the two

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah so this is a difficult question. ok so I think that even though some people get to go home for a lot of guys this is it and I have it's difficult for me to imagine thinking through the reality of a life sentence without parole in terms of how you cope with that this I mean I know that that's you want to keep hope alive somehow how do you cope with the possibility that this is the end of the road

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: My family. They did really keep my alive here. my communication with them is so beautiful when it comes down to me being locked up they really I've been here but to be honest I don't have much look for nothing good when I get legal mail because every time.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I get legal mail it's such a negative it ain't nothing good and with them telling me pray don't look at it like that it just keep me not feeling bad it just keep me just keep striving I mean here and there far as them telling me the things they telling me man it's kind of like my motivation.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I don't get if I'm here the only thing I get from here is negative it's the dark cloud and it hurt.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. So you turn to family and there are other guys that don't have that

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah. You are right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: A lot of people turn to god become religious do you see that quite a bit too?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah its that's one of the main thing that go on in here a lot of people turn Christian a lot of people put god first now a lot of people pray they tell you to pray but when you really not into changing man I don't care what they tell you not going to change you got to have it in your heart you got to want to change so what you hearing from other people just what you hearing but if you strive for it and change then that's what you going to wound up feeling

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok I think that's true so tell me a little bit about that you told me about that a little bit ago you said ok well now I'm humble people know who I am I don't have to do so tell me a little bit about the changes that you've gone through how are you at some point I would have hoped that you'd go before a pardon board and you have an opportunity to tell them I'm not the same person that came in that door.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can you tell me how you're different now from when you came here and everybody's different after 28 years right but how specifically are you different

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: My understanding is different my outlook is different I can cope with people I could talk with people I want to work with children I want to work with people that's going to do positive things I got patience I didn't have patience at first. I can go on and on but it's the main thing is man I got a heart now. I'm not blindsided. I was blind when I first come here now.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I'm not know what I'm saying I was a kid when I come here I was 19 I'm 47 now so it ain't that I was forced to change I just had to change. I had to change for myself and no keeping that bitter heart man it wasn't moving nothing and when I humbled myself and settled myself down I would be seeing a lot of positive things what I'm saying like talking to people.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: I couldn't talk to nobody about what was going on up here. I felt that like that was jive to tell another person about what's going on up here he better learn for himself like I did but no man that's not what's good just doing this and doing that. what's good is you being focused on what you got to do for to get out here that's what's good and not focusing on trying to get out which is bad which is going to cause you to become that's a ticket to the penitentiary

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Like I'm saying if you keep your head clean you keep your mind straight you going to win you could play football basketball. if you forget what you were in the penitentiary for you going to lose you going to be here like I've been here 20 years maybe even more

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You said that there's not much good here and you rely on family for the good things in your life. Are there anything is there anything good about this place?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: There ain't nothing good no nothing good about here man. It's here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah so you don't feel that you've there's a group of guys that would be your social support kind of like a family do you feel that that's.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah I could say that they have a few people in here that I really think I a friend of mine that makes since I've been in here I consider him my best friend and man this place isn't just its nothing about it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah can you tell me I think that even though this place has changed you've been here 28 years as you said you've done it been there done that seen everything here I expect you spent some time in the cell blocks when you first came here you've probably been around the whole place. What do you think is the hardest part of dealing with Angola today for you?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: The harder part of dealing with Angola today is trying to go home. Since day 1. Angola really it ain't really Angola man it's the personal man. It's you. Now you could survive anything if you really put your mind to it but if you don't put your mind to it you not going to survive and you really going to be living in on another person for your survival

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: But far as Angola right now today it's really not Angola it's really you really have a chance to really survive before going home and not being in here 28 years 30 years 40 years you really have a chance at having a short time in Angola cause you can focus you could focus on what you need to be focusing on.. And that's basically it

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can you tell me what your typical day is like what's your routine what do you do here in the prison.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Wake up pump iron then read and try to conversate with a lot of people that's basically it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you have a job here?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah I'm a tier walker.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay in which camp.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Right here in the main prison. Cell blocks.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh ok so tell me what you do what's that like?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Just walk the tier make sure nobody don't hurt they self and talk to them see where they mind at see where they feeling see that they ain't in no suicide state something like that there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So how long have you been doing that?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: About. It's been off and on I had like 6 months and they gave me another job and I come back to it so it's basically an off and on job for me being a tier walker.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay do you think you've been able to help some people?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah I been called on a few times to talk to this person and talk to that person what I'm saying they had sent for me to talk to me what I'm saying but yeah I done helped a few people.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay did you, you can you tell me a little bit have you taken advantage of some of the training programs that they have here or are there any organizations that you're a part of for example did you get your GED while you've been here?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: No I never got my GED because when I first come here life was couldn't really get really.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right I've heard that.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: so now you got a long line that waiting on for the GED test but I done took other classes like the JCs and substance abuse anger management 100 hours I'm trying to get me a trade now I'm trying to go to carpentry school I'm waiting on that I'm waiting on that yeah just waiting on that so I'm just waiting on them to call me for carpentry school.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I'm sure you've spent some time imagining what you would do on the outside because you seem very focused on getting out of here right? So tell me a little bit about what that vision looks like what would you be doing?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: First I'd celebrate, number one. I'd celebrate that I made the road that I'm about to go on the girl I'm with right now she's got a stable job she's got a nice job she work with cancer awareness department out there in Houston so that's probably where I'll be working with her something like that there. Because we done discussed that numerous times so I'll be alright I will be alright even if I have to go home even tomorrow.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah are you thinking about the idea of getting you talked about the idea of maybe going to carpentry school do you want to be able to use that on the outside?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah I've been.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Is that part of your thinking?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: Yeah it is. Because I'm going to need some type of trade when I go home I can't just go out there thinking I'm just going to get a job and not have no type of trade something that I know what I can do so I'm going to really do me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Kevin
transcript.content: So I'm going to really need I'm going to need a trade.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. Tell me the various things that you've done in your life including surviving through all this what do you feel you're most proud of?

transcript.speaker: Kevin
